title: Haggerty: Few women coach boys teams, but bias may not be to blame
text:
Haggerty: Few women coach boys teams, but bias maybe not to blame Nancy Haggerty , nhaggerty@lohud.com 2:54 p.m. EDT October 20, 2015 Buy Photo Horace Greeley's swim coach Meg Kaplan, at right, stretches swimmer Matthew Drucker during a team Dry Land workout at the school in Chappaqua Nov. 25, 2011. (Photo: File photo by Matthew Brown/The Journal News) Buy Photo 6 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Barring some major transgression, assistant coaches don’t get much ink. 
But there were headlines last year when the San Antonio Spurs hired former WNBA player Becky Hammon as an assistant and again this past summer, when she became head coach of its summer league team. 
The same thing occurred to a lesser extent when Nancy Lieberman, the face of women’s basketball from the late ‘70s through the ‘80s, was hired as a Sacramento Kings’ assistant this year. 
But they are exceptions. 
It’s common for men to coach women and girls. It remains uncommon for women to coach either men or boys, at least in team sports. 
Jen Welter’s appointment as an Arizona Cardinals “assistant coaching intern” was news last summer. 
Welter has a masters in sports psychology and a PhD in psychology. She played professionally for 14 years, including briefly in the Indoor Football League, which, otherwise, was for men only. 
But despite garnering praise for her work with Arizona’s linebacker corps, Welter wasn’t offered a job by the Cardinals or any other team once the preseason ended. 
Where professional sports is concerned, it’s easy and probably correct to mention closed doors and minds. 
But what about the high school level? Why are so few women hired to coach boys? 
Susan Dullea is one of eight female athletic directors in Section 1. She said females may have a tough time being considered for posts with boys teams in some locations, remarking, “I’m not naïve enough to think that doesn’t happen. There may be pockets.” 
But Dullea, who previously served as athletic director at Croton and Haldane, thinks bigger reasons are at play than isolated bias. 
While attending Ithaca College, she took courses in coaching football and baseball but did so because she wanted to learn from top coaches, not because she wanted to coach those sports. 
“I wanted to be a role model for young women. I wanted to coach the sports I played,” she said. 
Of bias keeping women from coaching boys teams, Meg Kaplan, longtime Horace Greeley boys swimming coach, said, “I don’t see that at all.” 
“Some places felt a man was a better coach,” she said, but that was decades ago. 
Boys swimming, like running, has multiple female coaches. But, as Kaplan noted, those are “individual sports with a team element,” rather than traditional team sports. 
While unsure why the numbers are low, she said high schools lose female coaches in general because home roles have remained much the same, while coaching demands have increased. Preseason practices begin earlier, seasons are long and games and meets now stretch into weekends. 
“It’s the total hours taken away from family. I think there are different commitments," she said, indicating she has been lucky because her husband has always been willing to handle child-related chores like dinner and homework while she’s at meets and practices. 
Bronxville’s 18-year athletic director, Karen Peterson, has never had a woman apply to coach a boys team. She attributes this partly to lingering perceptions. 
“I would think they don’t see it as an open market for them,” she said. “I think it’s what people think is accessible. … I think part of it is how you grow up and what you see around you.” 
In other words, if a female coach hasn’t seen another female coaching boys, she may not even think to apply for that job. 
There are exceptions. 
Keren Larkin took over as Carmel High varsity boys soccer coach last season. 
This year, Siobhan McDermott will be head boys junior varsity basketball coach at Woodlands and will be a bench coach for the varsity team for the second straight year. 
McDermott, who previously coached the girls varsity, was the boys modified (middle school) coach the past two years. She enjoys coaching boys, has gotten positive feedback from them, she said, and doesn’t know why there aren’t more women like her. 
But Larkin suggests young female coaches who aren’t teachers may think it difficult to gain the respect of boys. 
Larkin thinks she has been accepted in part because she plays co-ed soccer, including against some coaches of teams Carmel plays. “If I were not a good soccer player myself, it might be more difficult,” she said. 
Tess Brogan, Clarkstown North’s athletic director, said her school has had women coach boys cross-country, track and volleyball. 
“I think it ultimately comes down to who’s the best person for the job and who’s applying. I’ve certainly seen great success from the women coaching boys at the high school level,” Brogan said. 
And maybe with role models like Hammon, Lieberman and Welter, more women will apply to coach boys teams. 
Carmel currently has two openings for winter, including modified wrestling. Dullea noted she’d written a letter asking people to send potential candidates her way. She noted the letter says, “send him or her my way.” 
“It doesn’t matter what gender they are. It’s what they bring to the table," she said. "Do they know the sport?”
